qas.question: What was the only land mammal native to New Zealand?
Why were game animals introduced by acclimatisation societies?

answers.text: to provide New Zealanders with sport and a hunting resource

qas.question: Why did the population of pigs and rabbits explode in New Zealand?
What do government agencies view the animals as?
What country has a strong hunting culture?

context: <a5_0>New Zealand<a5_0/> has a <a0_0>strong <b12_0>hunting<b12_0/> culture<a0_0/>. The <a7_0>islands<a7_0/> making up New Zealand originally had no land mammals apart from <a1_0><a6_0><b10_0>bats<b10_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/>. However, once Europeans arrived, game animals were introduced by <a8_0><b13_0>acclimatisation societies<b13_0/><a8_0/> <a2_0>to provide New Zealanders with <b11_0>sport and a hunting resource<b11_0/><a2_0/>. Deer, pigs, goats, rabbits, hare, tahr and chamois all adapted well to the New Zealand terrain, and with <a3_0>no natural predators<a3_0/>, <a9_0>their population exploded<a9_0/>. Government agencies view the animals <b14_0>as <a4_0>pests<b14_0/><a4_0/> due to their effects on the natural environment and on agricultural production, but hunters view them as a resource.
